Title: Show that the determinant of $A$ is equal to the product of its eigenvalues
Content: Show that the determinant of a matrix $A$ is equal to the product of its eigenvalues $\lambda_i$. So I'm having a tough time figuring this one out. I know that I have to work with the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $\det(A-\lambda I)$. But, when considering an $n \times n$ matrix, I do not know how to work out the proof. Should I just use the determinant formula for any $n \times n$ matrix? I'm guessing not, because that is quite complicated. Any insights would be great.
AcceptedAnswer:
Suppose that $\lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_n$ are the eigenvalues of $A$ . Then the $\lambda$ s are also the roots of the characteristic polynomial, i.e. $$\begin{array}{rcl} \det (A-\lambda I)=p(\lambda)&=&(-1)^n (\lambda - \lambda_1 )(\lambda - \lambda_2)\cdots (\lambda - \lambda_n) \\ &=&(-1) (\lambda - \lambda_1 )(-1)(\lambda - \lambda_2)\cdots (-1)(\lambda - \lambda_n) \\ &=&(\lambda_1 - \lambda )(\lambda_2 - \lambda)\cdots (\lambda_n - \lambda)
\end{array}$$ The first equality follows from the factorization of a polynomial given its roots; the leading (highest degree) coefficient $(-1)^n$ can be obtained by expanding the determinant along the diagonal. Now, by setting $\lambda$ to zero (simply because it is a variable) we get on the left side $\det(A)$ , and on the right side $\lambda_1 \lambda_2\cdots\lambda_n$ , that is, we indeed obtain the desired result $$ \det(A) = \lambda_1 \lambda_2\cdots\lambda_n$$ So the determinant of the matrix is equal to the product of its eigenvalues.

Original Problem: Prove that if λ₁, λ₂, ..., λₙ are the eigenvalues of a matrix A, then the characteristic polynomial p(λ) can be expressed as p(λ) = (-1)^n (λ - λ₁)(λ - λ₂)⋯(λ - λₙ) and also as p(λ) = (λ₁ - λ)(λ₂ - λ)⋯(λₙ - λ).

Proof:
1. The characteristic polynomial is defined as p(λ) = det(A - λI).
2. Given that λ₁, λ₂, ..., λₙ are the eigenvalues of A (roots of the characteristic polynomial) with their respective algebraic multiplicities, the characteristic polynomial can be factored as p(λ) = c(λ - λ₁)(λ - λ₂)⋯(λ - λₙ).
3. The leading coefficient of det(A - λI) is (-1)^n. Therefore, c = (-1)^n.
4. So, p(λ) = (-1)^n (λ - λ₁)(λ - λ₂)⋯(λ - λₙ).
5. We can rewrite (-1)^n as (-1) × (-1) × ⋯ × (-1) (n times).
6. Distributing one (-1) to each factor (λ - λᵢ):
   p(λ) = [(-1)(λ - λ₁)] × [(-1)(λ - λ₂)] × ⋯ × [(-1)(λ - λₙ)]
7. Since (-1)(λ - λᵢ) = (λᵢ - λ), we can substitute this into the expression:
   p(λ) = (λ₁ - λ)(λ₂ - λ)⋯(λₙ - λ).
8. Thus, the characteristic polynomial can be expressed in both equivalent forms.
final: The proof is correct. The characteristic polynomial p(λ) can be expressed as p(λ) = (-1)^n (λ - λ₁)(λ - λ₂)⋯(λ - λₙ) and also as p(λ) = (λ₁ - λ)(λ₂ - λ)⋯(λₙ - λ).
